text:
Going on a 16 day tour of Italy in August/September. Doing Venice,Florence,Pisa,Rome,Naples and Sorrento.
Itinerary so far
VENICE 2 days
Boat transfer
Vivaldi Four Seasons Musici

FLORENCE 2 days
Bruellschis Dome & Cathedral Complex ticket

PISA 1 day
Pisa and Cathedral

ROME 4 days
Vatican and Catacombs

NAPLES 1 day
Pompeii

SORRENTO 5 days
Boat trip to Amalfi
Relax

What else should we do?
We have done Colosseum before.
We will do Spanish steps Pantheon and Trevi fountain. Is there anything else thats recommended in Rome?
Do you recommend a tour of Pompeii? We don't get to Naples till lunchtime and plan to do it this day then have a look around Naples in evening.
We have also done Blue grotto in Sorrento. Is there anything else you would recommend?
What else would you say is a must? Is there anything free that we can do as think I'm going to have to remortgage for this trip.
Any restaurant recommendations and any tips gratefully received.
Celebrating 35 years of NOT being married 😜

comments.comment_text: Too bad you don’t have more time in Florence to get out and see Tuscany.
While at the Vatican you must queue for St Peter’s Basillica. It’s breathtaking.

When we were in Sorrento, we took a shuttle over to Positano in the morning before it got too busy. One of the highlights of our trip for me. I had no agenda here, so when it did start to get a bit busy, I wasn’t bothered at all 🙂

if you've never been to Florence you should/must 🙂 see David! the Opera del Duomo is a beautiful museum, not sure what you mean by "tickets to the dome", are you climbing to the top? long climb, long line and IMO very overrated especially since you have only 2 days. that ticket includes the baptismal which is beautiful inside and worth a visit. walk across the Ponte Vecchio to the oltrarno (over side of the Arno river) and have a meal and look around, different from the south side of the river. if you're visiting the Uffizi book timed tickets, plan your visit as to what you want to see so you can utilize your time, the museum is huge and can take up valuable hours. August/
September is going to be HOT and very CROWDED, so be prepared! enjoy ... I love Italy <3
It looks like a great trip. While in Rome, a Piazza Navona, Campo de Fiori in the AM for a quick visit. Also recommend a small delicious museum with beautiful artwork, Borghese Gallery.

I would add a day to Florence! If you can get to San Gimignano I also recommend.
I loved and so glad I did not miss Pompeii.
I will gladly skip Pisa forevermore after just a couple of hours there.
Miss out Pisa and do 2 nights in Naples, totally chill in Sorrento.

I wrote a post here about nice things to do and see in Pisa!
In Rome there are many beautiful churches with great artwork: Santa Maria del Popolo, Santa Maria in Trastevere, San Giovanni in Laterano. Also Basilica di San Callisto, Galleria Borghese, a stroll in Trastevere area, in the Jewish Ghetto and Monti hill: they are all great! And check for Gianicolo!
Skip Pisa, drive to Lucca!
Take a boat to Capri.

Florence - wine window 🍷, piazza Michelangelo for free view of city
Rome- pantheon we booked online the day before, worth a look only €5
Pompeii is extremely hot - no shade, we entered when it opened at 9 it takes a good 3 hours but depends on temperature when you visit so afternoon may be ok

Take a Pompeii tour, most guides are archeologists. It by far the most fascinating place I’ve ever seen, you do not want to miss a thing by not having someone explaining it to you. I used the GetYourGuide to app to book all my tours. Take an early tour as it gets hot in the day.

Il Sorpasso is my favorite restaurant in Rome. I would add the Capitoline Museum to do in Rome or Breakfast at the Vatican which you can pre-book directly through the Vatican. No matter what, you’ll have a great time.

text:
Hi,
Are there any kid friendly wine tasting options on Tuscany? My son will be 12 yrs old.

Italy is more strict than Germany, it said on Google that they have to be at least 18 years old. In Germany, they can be 14 or younger with parental supervision.
Umm…
My sisters and I were all under legal drinking age the first time we went, we had no issues. Poggio antico

I’m sure the OP is asking for child friendly wineries. They wouldn’t be seriously asking if a 12yo can drink wine 😵‍💫

We went to a wine tasting at Verrazzano in Greve in Chianti with our son when he was 14- he enjoyed it. There were other families there with what looked like younger kids.
They had olive oil tasting too and I think you can book to have lunch there.

text:
Hello; questions about train in Italy (rome to Naples)

I have business class train booked with trenitalia.

Do I have to print my online ticket?

How do I know which part of the train to enter to get to business class or do I get on anywhere and walk through to find the business class area?

Thank you 🙂

comments.comment_text: We didn't print our tickets, we just gave our phone. Just ensure that if you purchase tickets at the station (for other routes) you validate it before you hop on. The validation machines are everywhere, the little machine before you get onto the train. On your ticket it will show you what carriage and there is numbers on the actual train. Each carriage is about 10 metres long. We did business class and found it easy. You just get there early to put your luggage in and you have an allocated seat xx

text: Where is the best place to shop in Italy?

comments.comment_text:
Mom and pop stores.
Where the locals shop.
Avoid tourist trap. Everyone thinks Americans are rich, so in a hot spot, you'll pay a premium.

There is no specific place! Obviously you shop Milano or other major cities you get hit harder… smaller cities and towns you will find Saldi ! The mercato always has fun stuff and some good quality for dirt cheap! The mercati differ from place to place as to when they operate. Last week I was lucky in Bari buying sandals at 32 euros or leather for 55 euros a pair.
Florence outlets - the mall was amazing!
If your looking to buy anything leather..it's Florence.
Stay out of all the tourist traps … shop at those tiny shops on the back streets
If you happen to be in Tuscany, visit mercato di Forte dei Marmi (on Wednesdays). They normally have stock from high end brands and you can try to bargain.
Everywhere

text: Best tours for Colosseum. Seeing underground and floor and palantine hill. Any thoughts?
If travelling from France to Italy can I just use my Carte de séjour or does it have to be my passport?

comments.comment_text: There are no passport controls in Schengen area of Europe so you shouldn’t need to show your passport even if going through Switzerland
You are in different country you have to have travel document with photo, which in Shengen is passport or identity card ;)despite the fact that there is no border control
You won't need anything when you cross borders within mainland Europe. When you arrive/leave or pass in/out of Schengen it must be your passport.
Your regular identity card is enough, as it is for all citizens within the Schengen area.
Thank you for the information

Your CDS is NOT a travel document....whi
lst border checks are uncommon thruout schengen, always best to travel with passport
You are still in Europe so you really don't need your passport BUT once I was advised at the airport to still take it along

text:
Good Morning,

I am planning to travel to Tuscany or Sicily
I just want to do both if they are close, I want the experience of the beautiful village cafes in the streets wine and beauty.
I will be there 8 days , what can you recommend ?
Also hotel or B&B
That is close to everything, I have traveled globally but never to Italy .
Thank you in advance!!

comments.comment_text: Simone Pfenninger

They are not close but you can fly from Pisa to Palermo (just an example). So you can do both, just plan well and book your planes from Tuscany to Sicily (which is huge so consider the area you want to visit very well and plan from there)

A little bit of distance between the two regions,

I’ll be honest and say 8 days split between two locations wouldn’t really give you time to fully appreciate either , you would lose a day travelling between the two even if you flew,

I’d decide on one or the other and really try and enjoy the experience rather than rushing it.

Rita Maria Velazquez Harb 8 days will barely cover a small part of the east coast of Sicily or alternatively the west coast & Palermo and Cefalu but it would be a complete rush job as it would with Tuscany. Book a week long tour and pick one destination. For 8 days in Tuscany I would book a tour that covers the main sights - Pisa, Siena, San Gimignano etc

Tuscany and Sicily are quite far from each other. I just returned from a trip to Tuscany we spent 10 days and drove around it was perfect 👌🏼You could definitely do it in a shorter period. We just wanted to take our time and relax since I’m pregnant. The heat in the summer is also something to consider in your timeline.
B&B in Tuscany - we definitely had a great experience at the Castillo di Spedaletto. They have 3 B&B in the castle we stayed at the il Mastio. Amazing experience!

It seems everyone has adequately addressed the distance, perhaps some folk could make some suggestions on both locations based what the OP is describing to help her inform her decision regarding which region to visit.
We’ve stayed on Sicily twice finding Catania absolutely wonderful. We were there for 10 days just 2 months ago.

Both areas are very beautiful. I loved Tuscany but Sicily captured my heart . 8 days isn’t a long time to do both justice at all as you will spend a day at least travelling between them . We spent 10 days in one area of Sicily and that wasn’t enough so maybe just do Tuscany and spend the time travelling through and enjoy this beautiful part of Italy
They aren’t close. I’d go Tuscany.
Choose one region or the other if your time is limited.
Not really close- but fast train will link you.

Taormina is besutiful we booked 2 days stayed 5! Plenty of trips to be had, stay in the upper town ....take the cable car down to the beach..
Were now in Cefalu for 3 nights..lovely.
...but hot!!! Lots of nice places to eat in Tairmina & Cefalu..
Montepulciano is gorgeous, we made a booboo with booking & ended up 7kms away..u need to be right in the centre if u have no car.
Theres a winery in the main street does free wine tours ..take it really interesting...
you can't do both in 8 days! Choose one area and focus on that. Also, depends on the time of the year, I wouldn't do Sicily in July or August.

8 days is a lovely amount of time to explore Tuscany and perhaps a bit of the coast. Use Florence or Siena as a base and do day trips for part of your time…and then maybe add Cinque Terre for a bit too. As part of a larger trip we did 4 nights Florence (with one tour to smaller villages and a winery for lunch), and 3 night at a remote winery/farm just outside of Riomaggiore. It was fantastic!
They aren’t close to eachother
What I’d do is stay in Florence for 4 or so days ( soooo much beauty there!) and from there travel to other cities like Siena, Lucca, Bologna, Pisa, even Venice…

I think if you have only 8 days, you have to choose one of the two region: they are not close and in both there’s really a lot to see!
I love better Sicily, but it’s just my opinion, actually are both very beautiful!

Thank you so much!🤗
I thank all of you , I am super excited. I guess from what I am reading Tuscany
Would be the best for the time I am going to be there , and then do Sicily on my next trip .

I will bother you all again and ask for suggestions in where I should stay ?
I want something quaint with the flavor of Italy not a typical American Hotel I have here or that I travel to on business.

As for the Summer Heat that is no problem I am From the US in Florida and it can’t get any hotter 😀
I really appreciate all your time in guiding me and sharing your experience and advice.
I hope to make my reservations soon once I know where I am going to stay and what airport I should fly into to get to Tuscany.
I want to just enjoy and relax and no stress and enjoy the beauty of Italy .
Once again thank you all so very much ☺️
They are not close

I just spoke to my travel person today about that also.It's doable you can fly from Florence to
Catania,VERY responsible and if need be Fly back to Rome from there (that's possibly our plan next spring) and back to NJ from Rome
Flight under 2 hrs fr Florence to Catania
I'd go Sicily. Can do a lot around Sicily in 8 days
They're not close. But you could easily fly from Pisa to Palermo or Catania.
You will need at least 2 weeks or more to scratch the surface of Sicilia. Take a look at an map of Italia and see how big the island is.

Hi I visited Sicily in may this year and I absolutely loved it! Not too hot or cold and I was there for a week and got to explore all of Catania city. I done a excursion trip to the valley of the temples which is full of monuments and Greek temples. I also visited pretty Taormina which has breathtaking views overlooking the blue sea.

text:
Have a trip planned to Italy in September.
When in Rome going to Vatican, Sistine Chapel, Colosseum do you have to have your shoulders covered as well as your knees?

comments.comment_text: Take a shawl or light sweater, it depends on who is on duty. Wait till you see how tourist dress. Wear your comfy clothes and shoes. I have pictures with men in shorts in the Vatican. I went in September.

Your shoulders will definitely have to be covered. As for knees if your dress or shorts are right at your knees they will probably not say anything. But it sort of depends on the guard. If you plan on trying to get in will knees uncovered I'd take a light shawl just in case so you can tie it around your waist if they object. And the truth is they don't seem to be as strict with men just so the shorts aren't super short.

text: Any beach/pool recommendations in Naples for next week please 🙏 🏖

comments.comment_text: There is no clean beach in Naples
We've booked a private beach and outdoor pool very exclusive Baia delle Rocce Verdi...you need to book in advance

Maybe you can plan a day trip to somewhere nearby with better options. Naples has a big, industrial port and is not a great place to be in the water. Capri, Ischia, and the Amalfi Coast are all great options
Day trip to Capri, Sorrento or Ischia is a great choice :)

text: So excited- all dining and activities are booked for our two week stay in Rome and amalfi coast.

Hello, I want to plan a trip to North Italy but only have a week. We will fly to Milan so this will be our base. There are so many options for day trips but we have to be selective. Which day trips do you think are worth it the most?

- Lake Como (will probably definitely visit)
- Cinque terre

I appreciate the opinion of those who have visited any of these areas. Thank you! 🙏🏼

comments.comment_text: What month- that matters.

Weather might be cool in N. Italy but not likely crowded. Easy train from Milan to Cinque Terra. Worth a 2-3 day trip- mostly if you like to hike. Many day hikes- not for the timid. Vertical climb up and down. Not dangerously but physical- hiking shoes and water. If rain, no hiking. We have been to a number of northern towns- loved Turin - medium size city- museums, food, walkable. Look at Asti and Alba too. They are all reachable by train. If you drive, be sure your accommodations include parking. Don’t get the car until you are out of Cinque Terra (they have no need for cars- train/ferry will do)

The Dolomites!! Anywhere in the Dolomites. You can take the gondolas for hikes and the most stunning views. Lago di Braies.
And If you choose Verona make sure you visit Lago di Garda.

If it is 7 full days I’d leave at least two days for Milan, then I would consider Lakes (there is more than one, Como but others are also really beautiful), Tourin (and if you have a car also Langhe area, near Alba and Barolo), Bologna, Ravenna and the Dolomites (but Dolomites you need a car). 5 Terre is really a long drive (3 hours train + plus the train you’ll have to do there) and I wouldn’t do it. Then obviously there is Venice but I assumed that if you didn’t put it in the list maybe you didn’t want it.
Genova covers 5 Terre and Portofino. Split your time

text:
Looking for recommendations for timing to go to Italy in 2025! Also, where to take my husband who’s a first timer to Europe, when I’ve (gratefully) been a few different times ☀️✈️🫶🏼

I’ve been to Italy twice;आणखी first time we did all the tourist spots during late July (Venice, Rome, Naples, Pomepi, & Sorrento), the second time was for study abroad in May-June and I did new spots (Tuscany - where we were based and did lots of day trips, Florence, Rome, Pisa, Verona, Milan, & Cinque Terre). We both enjoy trips that are a balance of fast paced and relaxation, so trying to find that balance!

Sharing this photo from my travels in Manarola!

comments.comment_text: You have hit a lot of spots. I have been to Italy twice and I think northern Italy is where it’s at! You can go to Milan and Venice but also cover Lake Como, Lake Garda and the Dolomites and lots more. And that provides fast pace and relaxation. I loved Lake Garda and Dolomites so much. I don’t hear many talk about this part of Italy much but it’s a change of pace, beyond your imagination magical and unlike most standard trips to Italy you will hear about. I love all the places I’ve been to in Italy. I will say the Italian Alps and northern Italy are just a bit different enough

It’s an open slather until you decide what part of Italy you’d like to focus on 🤷🏻‍♀️ We focus our trips on regions as best we can. I have a post that’s gone a little crazy on our trip south of Lake Como/Venice, if you can see it. Otherwise, we’ve done a lot of Tuscany, Cinque Terre, Amalfi coast, Lake shards, Ischia etc in previous trips. Feel free to shoot me any questions once you narrow down your region of choice!
Best advice take him to places you enjoyed.

Try something new for both of you. Maybe the Piemonte region, the Italian Alps and the Langhe wine region if you like that? Or head over to Puglia ( Polignano a mare, Ostuni, and the Adriatic. You could include Matera in the Basilicata region.
Go to Sicily or Puglia
Lake Como or Lake Garda! At Como, we stayed in Varenna. At Garda, we stayed in Sirmione.
Go South. Amalfi Coast then Ostuni, Tropea and Sicily.
Don’t go from May through Sept. Hot and crowded.

Been to Italy 4X…always October. Weather is perfect, crowds less and so is pricing.

How many places depends on length of your trip.

NORTH
I’d do Venice, Florence, Tuscany and Camogli (San Fruttuoso and Portofino for day trips). A bit of city, countryside and sea.

SOUTH
Rome, Naples, Ischia, Capri and Amalfi Coast.

Late September, early October is our favorite. Crowds less, prices usually less, weather generally amazing. Pick length of stay, look at airfare deals. We often base trip on entry airport and different exit airport. Try not to over schedule- travel from one city to the next can take up to 1 day. Spend 2-4 nights in each location or use a base city with a car (Tuscany, Umbria, Sicily we used Siracusa). I hope you can enjoy the planning as I do. Research and read reviews of accommodations.
Perla Ivonne Vargas Miranda
September and October
Have a wonderful time!

With two weeks, I think it's good to include Rome, Tuscany (Florence+count
ryside), and Venice; or Tuscany, Rome, and Sorrento/
Amalfi Coast.

You kind of answered your own question.. 🤓 I would have recommended a combo of the key tourist sites in Rome (Vatican City, Spanish Steps, Trevi Fountain, Colosseum etc), Pisa, Tuscany (pick your favourite places (Sienna etc).. I think Cinque Terre would be good or maybe go up to lake Como/Garda). If you have time/ budget take him to Sorrento/
Amalfi/Capri/
Pompeii? I loved Sorrento… even though this is an Italy page I’d get him to the Greek Islands too if you can (Santorini/
Paros/Naxos/
Mykonos/Crete)… still reckon they’re heaven on earth!😎
Head to beautiful lake.maggiore north of.milan.
Sicily my dear, Sicily in October

I travel annually to italy and have been consulted by family and friends on Italian travels. We come in the summer to stay on the Adriatic and enjoy sagras. However for touring I concur sept into early October is a good time period. Most people want to experience what we call the trinity- Rome Florence and Venice. Does he have a favorite place in mind? Logistics with your trip is key in ensuring both a relaxing and enjoyable experience. I suggest in Rome stay near the historic center. If Budget allows- you can get a car service to pick you up at Rome hotel early morning and drive to Positano/
Sorrento/
Pompeii and return in evening. Pricey but time effective. In Rome- golf cart tour is my suggestion. Remember to consider travel time when formalizing your itinerary. Enjoy
I love end of Sept. Early Oct.
I went in October and LOVED It
Beautiful pic.

Been to Italy many times and I strongly suggest Sardinia as something different … the other great thing we enjoyed immensely was truffle hunting near Sorrento. If you haven’t done Vatican City I would suggest this and also The last supper in Milan . 🙂

text: Hi all, is 15 to 30 April warm enough to travel in Italy (first Rome, then Florence and Venice)? How is the weather in second half of April? I need to confirm my flight dates and bookings and i am asking this to see if I can do my trip to Italy around second half of April and then travel to Germany, Swiss and France in May to visit old friends. I really appreciate your advice. Thanks very much.

comments.comment_text: I am also considering April or May to visit Rome and Florence. I look forward to the replies here!

Hi! In Italian🇮🇹
It’s spring, meaning you can experience a nice warm weather (20-25º) or cold and rainy days (10-15º). A lot of instability
I’d say April is better than May because in the last few years May has been really rainy to the point we have floods and landslides… so scary

if you come in april for two weeks, and visit those cities, you are likely to experience at least a few days of rain, the temperature may be between 10 on the coldest day, especially in venice, or even up to 25 on the warmest day, in rome. personally, i enjoy rome much better in spring than in the summer, i'd rather take some rain than the impossible heat of july or august. also, it will be less crowded and at least in rome probably warm enough to be able to enjoy an ice cream. so if i were you, i would book those tickets.

We were in Rome, Florence, Venice & Milan 6/4-25/4/23. Most days started cooler, around 12deg, & ended around 18-19deg. We had 3 days of lite rain, mainly in the morning. We walked around most places, & I was actually warm - spent most days with my jacket around my waist & just in a dress or T shirt. My husband was in jeans & a shirt the whole time. This was our day at the Coliseum, which was indicative of most of our days. ￼
Book away & enjoy!

I‘m looking at tha SSC Napoli game October 8 in Naples. I’m thinking of taking my chances and try when I get to Italy in September.

comments.comment_text: have you tried putting the phone of the hotel you are staying in? Just an idea

. Keep checking the website ,

Club website but Napoli have just won the league. About 20,000 people went to watch their first training session. I can imagine it will be very hard work getting a ticket as all the Napoli fans will buy them

Don't worry about being redirected to TicketOne, that's simply the website Napoli uses to sell their tickets. So it's the right website, it's not one of those shady third party websites. If anything, avoid other websites other than that one. Tickets for Napoli Fiorentina will probably be available not before September. Notice that the date of the game might be changed, it's possible that it's moved to the day before or the day after, it's something done routinely with every team to accommodate the needs of the television that airs the matches, so if you want to watch it you need to take this into account and plan accordingly with some flexibility.

We want to take the train to Cinque Terre and we will be traveling with my husband who uses a wheelchair. I have read conflicting reports about the feasibility of this. We know we won’t be able to do or see as much as those with no mobility issues but we are hoping to at least walk around a bit in the towns and have a snack or drink, see a few shops and just get to enjoy the vibe of the area. Possible?

comments.comment_text: The train trip along the coast is a nice trip. The stations from memory are at the top of the villages which are in a hill so getting down to the town on the path might be steep and difficult particle in busy times. Some are steeper than others. Porto Venere is a beautiful village at the end of the cirque Terre often over looked but I think the bus station and train station were flat and the village was easier to wander. Best of luck. Other villages along there worth wandering without the steep slopes are Rapallo, Santa Marguerita and Levanto.

Agree with Kerry Laux with enjoying the coast from the train. Get a seat on the right side of the train as you will be closer to the water and a better view. Portovenere is flat and lovely. I spent a few hours there wandering around and had a fantastic lunch. ❤️🇮🇹🇦🇺

Hi!
You can definitely go to Monterosso, which is the main “terra” (“cinque terre” means five lands/towns).
It’s bigger than the other Terre and not so steep as it’s at sea level and she even as a large beach.
Then you can visit the other Terre by train or better by boat
We didn’t do it but you can get a ferry from La Spezia that takes you round. Hop on and hop off. This would be an amazing view if you struggle with steps etc

If anyone has a health emergency you need you passport. Seems an exception but I have just got back today. So hot people dropping with heat exhaustion

I realize that few seem to care about the actual law, but, "According to the law DLGS N.286 of July 25th, 1998, it is mandatory that you always carry an international identification document (your passport) whenever you are in Italy, BUT, it doesn’t have to be the original document, it can be a copy."

https://

I kept paper copies in my travelon bag. They fold up small and were accepted everywhere.
We were asked to show ours by officers. We asked the question out of curiosity if copies were acceptable. Answer was no. Actual passport required.

Make a high quality color copy to carry with you around town- also carry a copy of your hotel receipt because they by late need to copy your PP. However, if you take a train out to another station carry you actually PP- higher likelihood that’s where they are checking.

If you’re going to hire audio guides at museums etc you should have your drivers license with you to leave in exchange. I wouldn’t leave a passport with them. We had a paper version and an electronic one should we be asked for our passport. In a month we were never asked for it, but when photo I’d was required the licence was fine.

I usually carry a color copy of the passport and leave it in the safe in the hotel. I also take a snapshot of the passport in my phone as a backup.
One time I wanted to get a small scarf at the Channel store, they refused to take the copy of the passport. They told me to get the real passport in order to get the VAT tax back. They said it is the company’s policy. Same thing for most of the designer store.
I had both a hard copy as well as having a photo on my phone and it was also saved in my Google Account.

text: With an upcoming trip planned and the recent heat wave wondering if we should bring our reusable water bottles. From staying with family and hotels many years ago I know ice machines were few and far between…is that still the case? It’s been 16 years since I have been.

comments.comment_text: Yes, do bring them! Ice machines are not common, but for example in Rome there are water fountains everywhere and the water is quite cold, as the taps are kept running.
We don't use ice as much as you do in the USA but if you bring a water bottle with a wide neck people will give you ice for your water.
We brought ours and filled them half way at night and put them in the freezer! Then we had ice in them for when we went out!
Definitely bring your water bottles and refill them multiple times a day! Italian cities have drinking fountains.

text: Heading to Italy, and anywhere overseas actually, for the first time in September. This page has been very helpful. I’m traveling alone, and am curious how much and what denominations of coins should I bring? I’ve seen posts about pay toilets, and definitely want to have proper change! Thanks 😊

comments.comment_text: You really need a small coin purse and just collect them as you go in change, ie have some notes and pay with them now and again.
I carried €1 coins only. I did find that 3 out of our 5 hotels asked for tourist tax in cash only so made sure we had that in hand.

Public toilets vary from 50 cents to €1 but if you use ones in cafes/
restaurants/
museums etc then no charge (obviously have to buy a drink or something).
1 euro coins plus 50 centimes will be your friend, but ultimately just gets drink at a cafe and use their toilets for free most of the time. Never not use a toilet when it is free!
Go to the toilet in cafes and bars. You can just order a coffee and use the toilet while there.

In Canada currency exchange does not have coin, starts at €5 and up. So when you arrive at the arrive port buy a bottle of water give a €10, then buy a chocolate bar elsewhere same process. Now you have some small change.
When you arrive buy something to get coins smaller than 5 euro. Keep those if needed for public restrooms. Some have an attendant and are clean.

Back in 2019 My (then) 17 year old daughter lived and studied abroad in Rome for 6 months. Every time she would go out to eat with her host family (or us when we visited) she was asked by servers if she wanted to other a glass of wine (or after meal liquor) without even asking her for proof of age. She went to many of her local high school parties (Halloween, New Years, etc) and noticed young people drink responsibly and in moderation. She was (and still is) not a drinker and unlike in the U.S., never felt peer pressure from her Italian program or high school friends to drink. Many parts of the world don’t have the drinking problem we see in the U.S. among our youth. As someone who was born and raised abroad, I remembered being taught since a very early age how to drink a very small amount of wine with our meals. To this day (and at 58 years old), I still drink do the same way.
